input: Question: Tell me a bio of Alfred Hitchcock.

He directed over fifty feature films in a career spanning six decades, becoming as well-known as any of his actors thanks to his many interviews, his cameo roles in most of his films, and his hosting and producing of the television anthology Alfred Hitchcock Presents (1955–1965). His films garnered a total of 46 Oscar nominations and six wins. He also received two Golden Globe Special Achievement Awards. Hitchcock's films featured a range of psychological suspense and thrilling plots and he often employed elements of horror, comedy, and the fantastic. His films included some of the most famous and critically acclaimed in cinematic history, such as Notorious (1946), Rear Window (1954), Vertigo (1958), Psycho (1960), The Birds (1963), and Frenzy (1972).

input: Question: Tell me a bio of Bobby Fischer.
output: Bobby Fischer (1943-2008) was an American chess grandmaster and the 11th World Chess Champion. He is widely considered one of the greatest chess players of all time. He won the 1963/64 U.S. Championship with the score of 11-0, the only perfect score in the history of the tournament. He also won the World Chess Championship in 1972, becoming the first American to do so. Fischer was known for his intense and unorthodox style of play, and his deep study of the game. He wrote several books on chess, including My 60 Memorable Games. After the 1972 World Championship, Fischer largely disappeared from public life and devoted himself to studying chess. He died in 2008 at the age of 64.

input: Question: Tell me a bio of George VI.
output: George VI (Albert Frederick Arthur George; 14 December 1895 – 6 February 1952) was King of the United Kingdom and the Dominions of the British Commonwealth from 11 December 1936 until his death in 1952. He was the last Emperor of India and the first Head of the Commonwealth. In 1923, he married Lady Elizabeth Bowes-Lyon, and they had two daughters, Elizabeth and Margaret. During his reign, George VI faced many personal and public challenges, including the abdication of his brother, Edward VIII. He was known as a conscientious, hardworking monarch who was committed to his duty as a constitutional monarch. He was also a strong supporter of the British Empire and the Commonwealth. He was an accomplished painter and enjoyed horse racing, cricket, and stamp collecting. He was a patron of the arts and sciences and was awarded honorary degrees from several universities. George VI died in 1952 and was succeeded by his daughter, Queen Elizabeth II.

input: Question: Tell me a bio of Marcus Aurelius.

input: Question: Tell me a bio of Henry VII of England.

His political career began in the 1900s, when he was elected to the British Parliament from Oldham. He quickly rose through the ranks of the Conservative Party and was appointed Home Secretary in 1910. He became Prime Minister in 1940, inspiring the British people to fight for victory against Nazi Germany. He led Britain through the dark days of World War II and is remembered for his unwavering leadership and refusal to compromise. After the war, he continued to serve as Prime Minister until 1955. He died in 1965 at the age of 90.

input: Question: Tell me a bio of Vladimir Lenin.

input: Question: Tell me a bio of Nelson Mandela.
output: Nelson Mandela (1918-2013) was a South African anti-apartheid revolutionary, politician, and philanthropist who served as President of South Africa from 1994 to 1999. He was the country's first black head of state and the first elected in a fully representative democratic election. Mandela was born to the Thembu royal family in Mvezo, British South Africa. As an activist against apartheid, he was repeatedly arrested for seditious activities and served a sentence of life imprisonment in the 1980s. Upon his release in 1990, Mandela led negotiations with President F. W. de Klerk to abolish apartheid and establish multiracial elections in 1994, in which he was elected President. During his presidency, Mandela focused on dismantling the legacy of apartheid by tackling institutionalized racism and fostering racial reconciliation. He was internationally acclaimed for his activism, having received more than 250 honors, including the 1993 Nobel Peace Prize. He is often referred to by his Xhosa clan name, Madiba, and is often described as the "Father of the Nation" in South Africa.

input: Question: Tell me a bio of Muhammad Ali Jinnah.
